Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Diet description and feeding group assignment of nearshore marine fishes (blennies) in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
Blennies are small marine fishes (400 species), commonly found in tropical reefs. Most blennies are food specialists feeding on detritus (decomposing material), algae, pieces of other fishes, or invertebrates. Blennies have higher speciation rates (process of new species arising) than other fishes and this may be driven by diet specialization accompanied by evolution of structures such as jaws and teeth. Unfortunately the diet of many blennies is poorly described, and in some species, completely unknown. This research will provide a description of diet and feeding group assignment of blennies from Taiwan. This is part of a larger study examining the correlation between diet and feeding structures and the evolutionary relationships of blennies. This study will be conducted at National Chiayi University, in collaboration with Dr. Chien-Hsien Kuo, a fish biology expert. Taiwan is an ideal setting due to the high diversity of blenny species.

The diet of blennies is poorly known but critical to an understanding of the evolution of trophic morphology. This study will collect 66 blenny species from subtidal, intertidal and supralittoral habitats in Taiwan. Dissection and gut content analysis will be conducted. Cluster analysis methods will be used to test for similarities among diet between species and test the following hypotheses: 1) co-occurring blenny species exhibit significant overlap in diet, 2) diet is species specific, regardless of community structure, i.e. species occurring in multiple sub-habitats will not exhibit significant variation in diet. Results of this diet study will provide the first description of diet for some blenny species and add previously described diets. Ultimately, diet data will be used in conjunction with morphological and molecular data to test hypotheses about evolution of diet and feeding morphologies of blennies. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this study was to describe the diet, collect tissues for future DNA extraction, and obtain voucher specimens for morphological investigation of a group of common, near shore marine fishes. Blennies (Family Blenniidae) are found in most marine habitats throughout the tropics and subtropics. They are of interest to biologists because they exhibit a vast array of oral tooth and jaw morphologies, unique among fishes. This includes teeth that widely vary in shape, number, and mode of attachment and replacement, and a lower jaw that has an extra articulation. These feeding morphologies are often highly correlated with diet and may have played an important role in the evolutionary history of blennies. In order to study the correlation of diet and feeding morphologies or structures, diet data must be available. Unfortunately, the diet of many blennies is poorly known.

Blenny specimens, representing twenty-three species, were collected using hand nets, aided by snorkel in Taiwan. Collecting trips were conducted in nearly all regions of the island, including three islands off the main island. Preserved blennies were dissected in a laboratory at Chiayi University and stomach contents were identified with the aid of a light microscope. Diet data were added to previously collected data and an analysis was conducted that clustered similar blenny diets into feeding groups, which provides insight into which species have similar diets. In addition to diets, tissues were collected for future extract DNA to be used in an evolutionary study of relationship of blennies.

This study provides a detailed description of the diet of twenty-three blenny species from Taiwan and adds. Many different food items were found in the stomach contents of blennies, including fish scales, copepods, coral polyps, algae, and detritus. The cluster analysis including species sampled in Taiwan and from past studies grouped blennies (61 total species) into 9 distinct trophic guilds, covering a wide range of specialist (e.g. fish scale eaters) and generalist (e.g. omnivores) diets. The majority of species clustered into a large group that mainly consumed detritus, a highly specialized diet possibly correlated with unique feeding structures of blennies. The diet data collected in this study are a crucial component of a larger study, which aims to investigate the evolution of feeding morphologies and structures of blennies.


Last Modified: 02/28/2015
Modified by: Peter J Hundt
